Indian government may reportedly soften stance in seeking RBI capital, according to local press reports. (Newswires)

UK

UK PM May said Brexit talks are now reaching their "endgame" and that both sides working hard to reach an agreement but added that significant issues still remain and that the government will not accept a deal at any cost. Furthermore, there were later reports that UK PM May had rejected the latest draft Brexit deal with the EU as it didn’t provide a clear exit from the customs union if the EU began acting in bad faith in discussions regarding a future trade agreement. (Newswires/The Sun)

Senior ministers led by UK Brexit Secretary Raab tell UK PM May no deal is preferable to the current offer from the EU and that the current deal will not get through Parliament. (Buzzfeed)

EU's Chief Negotiator Barnier said no Brexit agreement reached yet and is reportedly to tell EU27 the parameters of agreement clarified. In separate reports, EU's Chief Negotiator Barnier said the Brexit treaty text is almost ready and that the main elements of the text are ready to present to the UK cabinet on Tuesday according to FT citing sources, although a UK PM May spokesman later said the Barnier report in the FT should be treated with scepticism. (FT/Newswires)

Dutch Minister Blok reported that EU Chief Negotiator Barnier stated that the UK and EU are getting closer to a deal, while he added it is not true Brexit deal is done as it is more complicated than that. (Newswires)

Political Editor of The Sun Tom Dunn tweeted that EU’s Tusk told No 10 that a deadline for a November summit is this Wednesday night and it appears that the government is beginning to give up hope for one, while Whitehall sources suggested to not get your hopes up. (Twitter)

Business Insider reported that UK PM May will trigger no deal Brexit plans this week unless there is a deal, while it added that the Cabinet will meet on Tuesday to discuss the precarious state of Brexit talks. (Business Insider)

ITV's Robert Peston said If UK PM May puts version of Withdrawal Agreement and Northern Ireland backstop currently insisted upon by Brussels to Cabinet tomorrow, there is big danger the cabinet will reject it, citing ministers. (Twitter)


EU

ECB's Lautenschlaeger (Hawk) said she is very much in favour of ending the asset purchase programme, while she also favours designing reinvestments in a flexible way and not too long. (Newswires)

Italy's PM Conte would not be holding a budget meeting ahead of the re-submission deadline tomorrow according to the PM's office. In addition, Italy's Deputy PM Di Maio said respecting EU's limits on the budget is suicide, while Deputy PM Salvini said fundamentals of the budget will not change. However, there were also reports that Italian Deputy PM's Salvini and Di Maio had a "positive" meeting with PM Conte on the budget; according to an official. (Newswires/ANSA)
 

COMMODITIES

US President Trump tweeted "Hopefully, Saudi Arabia and OPEC will not be cutting oil production. Oil prices should be much lower based on supply!". (Twitter)

OPEC Secretary General Barkindo said oil demand growth is to be below 1.5-1.6mln BPD in 2019 and that he is confident of continued OPEC+ cooperation. (Newswires)
 

US

Fed's Daly (Voter) said she will not be surprised by a December hike and sees at least a couple of hikes in 2019, while she added the Fed should head towards neutral and are not there yet. Furthermore, Daly added neutral is uncertain so doesn't see it as a stopping point and noted Fed's gradual approach is aimed at a soft landing for the economy. (Newswires)

US Commerce Department is reportedly circulating a draft report on auto tariffs and reports noted that US President Trump is to plan meeting on Tuesday with trade team regarding the auto report. (Newswires)
 

MARKET RECAP

Apple (AAPL) traded lower on reports from one of its suppliers, Lumentum Holdings (LITE), had lowered its guidance due to a large cut in orders from one of its large customers, rumoured to be Apple. Nektar Therapeutics (NKTR) was a top mover following positive data from its melanoma treating drug. Athenahealth (ATHN) surged on the back of Veritas Capital and Elliot Management acquiring it. The day also gave gains to several utilities such as Dominion Energy (D), American Electric Power (AEP) and Xcel Energy (XEL). Utilities with large exposure to the California wild fires were some of the day’s biggest losers, with stocks PG&E (PCG) and Edison International (EIX) both down. Tobacco stocks Altria Group (MO) and Philip Morris (PM) dropped following reports that US regulators are seeking to ban menthol cigarettes. SPX 2726% at -1.97%, NDX -2.98% at 6829, DJI -2.32% at 25387.

Treasury futures were thin, with cash markets closed for Veteran’s Day, leaving the complex to trade off broader risk themes. With the risk-off tone begotten by a stronger USD, weighing on equities, and seeing the VIX rise above 20, the mood was defensive, and as such, Treasuries rose. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 8+ ticks higher at 118-12+.

US MARKET WRAP – 12th November 2018: Trump jawbones oil prices; tech leads stock losses   

* SNAP-SHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, dollar up, crude down.

* REAR-VIEW: EU’s Barnier says Brexit agreement not reached yet, Italy holds positive talks ahead of tomorrow’s budget deadline, BoE's Broadbent sees weaker UK growth in Q4, EU’s Juncker to avoid escalation of trade tensions with US.

* AHEAD: Italian Budget Resubmission Deadline, German CPI (Final), UK Unemployment Data, Japanese GDP (Q3), ECB’s Praet, Lautenschlager, Stournaras and de Guindos, Fed’s Harker, Brainard and Daly.

 

* BREXIT: EU’s Chief Negotiator Barnier on Monday said that no Brexit agreement has been reached yet and he is to tell EU27 the parameters of an agreement. Also, a PM May spokesperson warned that reports in the FT stating that a Brexit treaty text is almost ready and that the main elements of the text will be presented to the UK cabinet on Tuesday, should be treated with scepticism. Separately, UK PM is struggling to secure a deal on her side, with some now seeing an EU summit being pushed from November to December 13th/14th, and a meaningful vote to January. There were also suggestions that no cabinet agreement could trigger a no-deal Brexit this week. Elsewhere, a spokesman reassured that there are no signs that other ministers are thinking about resigning, adding the Cabinet has backed PM May in moving forward on a Brexit deal, and he expects the Cabinet to continue to do so. Later, reports emerged that senior ministers led by UK Brexit Secretary Raab told PM May that no deal is preferable to the current offer from the EU, Buzzfeed reported, saying current deal would not get through Parliament; Raab told colleagues that no deal is better than current deal.

* ITALY: Ahead of tomorrow’s budget resubmission deadline, an official reported that Italian Deputy PM's Salvini and Di Maio had a "positive" meeting with PM Conte on the budget whilst EU Commission President Juncker said to be "moderately concerned" about Italy's relation; he added that the country is moving away from the minimum requirements of the stability pact. With regards to economic forecasts, an Italian Parliament watchdog expects Italy's deficit/GDP to stand at 2.6% in 2019 whilst seeing the 2019 growth target as "increasingly ambitious"; note the Italian government’s forecasts a deficit of 2.4% and the EU Commission a deficit of 2.9%. There were also reports suggesting Italy was seeking to lower its budget 2019 growth forecasts to between 1.0%-1.2% from 1.5% to get an EU budget deal.

* TRADE: EU President Juncker said the bloc is negotiating with White House officials at all levels to avoid an escalation of trade tensions. In separate news, the US is planning to introduce export controls to fight China intellectual property theft, according to the WSJ. Elsewhere, it was reported that the US Commerce Department was circulating a draft report on auto tariffs with US President Trump set to plan meeting on Tuesday on the auto report.

* FED: Fed's Daly (Voter) said she will not be surprised by a December rate hike and sees at least a couple of hikes in 2019; she believes the Fed should head towards neutral and it is not there yet. She also noted that neutral is uncertain and she does not see it as a stopping point. She stated the Fed's gradual approach is aimed at a soft landing for the economy. Later she added that the labour market is booming, the US is at or beyond full employment and economic conditions merit gradual normalisation of monetary policy. Finally, she sees inflation rising to a bit above 2% over the next year.

* BOE: BoE's Broadbent (Neutral) said there are signs that there will be somewhat weaker UK economic growth in Q4, adding that UK wage growth is materially higher and is now seeing signs of domestic inflation pressure. He clarified that a limited and gradual rate guidance does not mean one rate hike per year precisely, stressing that the important thing is to reassure people that the BoE would not have to engage in very steep series of rate hikes. He noted an intensification of drag on business investment related to Brexit and argued that having or not having a Brexit deal is not definitive in terms of setting interest rates.

* ECB: ECB's Lautenschlager (Hawk) said she is very much in favour of ending the asset purchase programme and of designing reinvestments in a flexible way and not too long.

* SPX 2726% at -1.97%, NDX -2.98% at 6829, DJI -2.32% at 25387. SECTORS: Energy -2.3%, Materials -1.49%, Industrials -1.98%, Cons Discretionary -2.31%, Cons Staples -0.65%, Healthcare -1.39%, Financials -2.01%, Tech -3.54%, Telecoms -1.48%, Utilities -0.03%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Apple (AAPL) traded lower on reports from one of its suppliers, Lumentum Holdings (LITE), had lowered its guidance due to a large cut in orders from one of its large customers, rumoured to be Apple. Nektar Therapeutics (NKTR) was a top mover following positive data from its melanoma treating drug. Athenahealth (ATHN) surged on the back of Veritas Capital and Elliot Management acquiring it. The day also gave gains to several utilities such as Dominion Energy (D), American Electric Power (AEP) and Xcel Energy (XEL). Utilities with large exposure to the California wild fires were some of the day’s biggest losers, with stocks PG&E (PCG) and Edison International (EIX) both down. Tobacco stocks Altria Group (MO) and Philip Morris (PM) dropped following reports that US regulators are seeking to ban menthol cigarettes.

* WTI (Z8) SETTLES USD 0.26 LOWER AT USD 59.23/BBL, BRENT (F9) SETTLES USD 0.06 LOWER AT USD 70.12/BBL. Crude closed lower for the 11th consecutive day after US President Trump stated that “oil prices should be much lower based on supply” and that he hopes Saudi Arabia and OPEC will not be cutting production. Signs that OPEC/non-OPEC partners may reverse policy at its December meeting had previously provided support to the complex earlier on Monday. The weekend JMMC meeting showed an emerging consensus that members are leaning towards production cuts; Saudi Arabia indicated that production may need to be trimmed by as much as 1mln barrels to ensure a balanced market, adding that its own exports in December may fall 500k BPD MoM due to year-end seasonal factors. The Russians, however, were not as pessimistic; energy minister Novak said it was not certain that crude markets would be oversupplied in 2019, and OPEC's SecGen Barkindo sees an oil market balance in Q4. Separately, the Saudis were said to be surprised that the US had granted waivers to eight nations on Iranian sanctions, Reuters reported citing sources, and some have suggested that the more hawkish rhetoric from may be an attempt to arrest the recent slide in crude prices, after last week both Brent and WTI entered bear-market territory.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLES 8+ TICKS HIGHER AT 118-12+. Treasury futures were thin, with cash markets closed for Veteran’s Day, leaving the complex to trade off broader risk themes. With the risk-off tone begotten by a stronger USD, weighing on equities, and seeing the VIX rise above 20, the mood was defensive, and as such, Treasuries rose.

* DXY: The index remains comfortably above 97.000 and not far from fresh 2018 peaks (97.583), but lost some momentum vs G10 rivals as the likes the Gbp clawed back lost ground, and certain EMs bucked the wider trend of underperformance – such as the Try (above 5.4500 in wake of improved Turkish current account balance) and Rub (benefiting from the Brent bounce to circa 67.65).

* GBP: The Pound got a lifeline from the EU amidst ongoing in-fighting and division within UK parliament, as chief negotiator, although underlining that a deal is not yet done. Cable reclaimed the 1.2900 handle, after Barnier stated that the ‘main’ components of a Brexit withdrawal agreement are ready to be put before the Cabinet on Tuesday, having earlier pared some losses from around 1.2825 as a spox for PM May denied reports that Ministers are ready to resign in protest at the Brexit blueprint presented last week and following a Wednesday deadline set by EU’s Tusk in order to allow time for an end of November Summit. Eur/Gbp recoiled from nearly 0.8775 to 0.8710 accordingly, with the single currency suffering from its own specific negative weights (see below).

* EUR: Not much respite or sign of a last minute coming together between Italy and the EU on the budget front as tomorrow’s deadline for Rome to re-submit its fiscal plan fast approaches, as early talk about a meeting to discuss the draft involving PM Conte and Deputies Di Maio and Salvini did not materialise, at least officially. Hence, after tripping mega stops at/around the old ytd base circa 1.1300, selling pressure intensified to sub-1.1250 at one stage, and with only shallow bounces thereafter.

* AUD, CHF: Both lagging vs the Greenback, with the former unable to rebound far above 0.7200 amidst ongoing US-Chinese trade angst and reports that Washington may deploy export controls in its efforts to thwart IP theft, as the Cnh edged closer towards the 7.0000 level vs the Usd that is deemed to be a line in the sand. Meanwhile, the France struggled at the low end of 1.0105-1.0050 trading parameters but rebounded firmly vs the Eur from 1.1400 and below the big figure during recent sessions.

* CAD, JPY, NZD: Relative outperformers, or at least more resilient than major rivals vs the broadly strong Usd, with the Loonie managing to stay within touching distance of 1.3200 and underpinned by a rebound in crude. The Jpy saw more recovery gains from a 114.20 low towards 113.70 as risk sentiment soured again, while the Kiwi derived independent impetus from favourable cross-winds as Aud/Nzd slipped through 1.0700 and Nzd/Usd hovered around the top of a 0.6705-55 band.

  • Apple (AAPL) – JP Morgan negative on iPhone EMS players. Separately, issues were found related to a component failure in some iPhone X and 13-inch MacBook pro and the tech giant stated it would solve them free of charge.  (Newswires)
  • Merck (MRK) – The pharma giant has received FDA approval for its anti-PD-1, Keytruda therapy for hepatocellular carcinoma. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • Abiomed (ABMD) – The med-tech co. releases results from its FDA STEMI Door-to-Unloading trial where it showed safety from its use. (Newswires)
  • Cambpell Soup (CPB) – The co. offered to add two Third Point nominees, Kurt Schmidt and Sarah Hofstetter, to its board the hedge fund rejected a similar proposal. (Newswires)
  • Praxair (PX), Linde (LIN) - Linde's Praxair unit has signed a long-term agreement to supply Fulcrum's Sierra bio-fuels plant in Nevada where it will build two vacuum pressure swing adsorption plants, expected to start in early 2020. (Newswires)
  • Tobacco names (MO, PM) - An FDA Commissioner is reportedly pursuing a ban on menthol cigarettes as they pose a greater health risk than normal cigarettes. (Newswires)
  • Twitter (TWTR) – The social platform attempted to make users’ counts of followers more accurate on Friday after a major clearance was made in June over millions of suspicious followers which have reappeared. (Newswires)
  • UPS (UPS) – The shipping co. has reached a five-year agreement with the Teamsters Union and as of such avoided a nation-wide strike. (Newswires)
  • Wells Fargo (WFC) – The bank has fired two employees after a probe into its negotiation and procurement of low-income housing credits. (Newswires)
  • Barron’s writes that now could be the time to sell and take profits from Kroger (KR) as it has outperformed its prior target and is trading at a higher than equilibrium p/e ratio. (Barron’s)
  • Barron’s writes that there is plenty of headroom for the aerospace sectors with stocks mentioned such as Boeing (BA), Lockheed Martin (LMT) and General Dynamics (GD). (Barron’s)
  • Barron’s writes that Dollar Tree (DLTR) is currently a “bargain” and that since its acquisition of Family Dollar the market has punished its stock too far. (Newswires)
  • Barron’s writes that the ex-CEO of Wynn Resorts (WYNN), Steve Wynn, showed “impeccable timing” with the sale of his stake in the co. in March, since then the share price has plummeted. (Barron’s)

NASDAQ

  • Alphabet (GOOGL), Facebook (FB) – French minister Bruno Le Maire said that the EU is close to implementing a digital tax. The German Finance Minister Olaf Scholz added that he favours the agreement that France has proposed and wants a deal at the December meeting. (Newswires)
  • Amazon (AMZN) – Nomura raises its price target on the stock to USD 2,050 from USD 1,990 stating the retail giant cannot suppress growth any longer. (Newswires)
  • Facebook (FB) – The social media giant has removed its policy that required staff to settle sexual harassment claims in private arbitration, this comes just after Google (GOOGL) removed its same policy. Elsewhere the WSJ also reports that former executive Palmer Luckey was fired after he donated USD 10,000 to an anti-Hilary Clinton group in the 2016 presidential election. Also, the social media rejected a request from the Singapore government to remove an online article labelled "false and malicious".  (WSJ/ Newswires)
  • Micron (MU) - US planning to use export controls to combat China intellectual property theft, WSJ reports, launched with a crackdown on a Chinese chip maker accused of stealing from Micron. (WSJ)
  • NetEase (NTES) – The Chinese internet co. announced its music streaming unit has completed its round of financing, raising over USD 600mln from partners including Baidu (BIDU). (Newswires)
  • Netflix (NFLX) – The streaming co. has said it has no intention of lowering its prices in the competitive India market. Elsewhere, Piper Jaffray has said the co. is well positioned for price raises after a survey revealed sentiment for the quality of its content improving. (Newswires)
  • Regeneron (REGN) – The pharma co., alongside the France-based Sanofi (SAN FP), released mortality analyses from its ODYSSEY outcomes trial, where it showed that patients with the Praulent injection had a reduced risk of suffering a heart attack. (Newswires)
  • Shire (SHPG) – Takeda Pharmaceuticals is looking to close its USD 62bln acquisition of Shire by January 8th, 2019. (Newswires)
  • Tech Giants (MSFT, FB, GOOGL) – French President Macron, alongside tech giants, are looking to get a new initiative signed by governments and companies across the globe that will help regulate the internet from hate speech and cyber-attacks. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Alibaba (BABA) – The Chinese online retailer brought in USD 30.7bln in sales for its Single’s Day, a new record, but the growth rate was the slowest ever and less than expectations. (Newswires)
  • Apptio (APTI) – The software co. has been acquired by Vista Equity Partners for USD 1.94bln or USD 38/shr, expected to close in Q1 2019. (Newswires)
  • Athenahealth (ATHN) – The healthcare co. is to be acquired for USD 5.5bln or USD 135/shr by both Veritas Capital and Elliott Management. (Newswires)
  • Lumentum (LIT) – The co. cuts Q2 ADJ. EPS view to USD 1.15-1.34 from USD 1.60-1.75 and revenue view to USD 335mln-355mln from USD 405mln-430mln after citing a cut in orders from one of its largest customers which is believed to be Apple (AAPL). (Newswires)
  • Nektar (NKTR) – The pharma co. presented data from its Phase 1/2 study of the Melanoma treating NKTR-214 with nivolumab (PIVOT-02), where it showed promising results of anti-tumour activity. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

Upgrades

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 12th November 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European equities are mixed after having initially opening higher across the board, DAX underperforms while FTSE 100 is buoyed by a weaker GBP
  • DXY has extended recovery gains beyond 97.000 and through its previous ytd peak to top out just shy of 97.600
  • Looking ahead, the calendar includes a lack of tier 1 data, ECB’s Lautenschlaeger, Fed’s Daly. US Veteran’s Day – no market closures

 ASIA

Asian equity markets eventually traded mostly positive but with gains limited as some cautiousness lingered from the uninspiring performance on Wall St last Friday, where ongoing global growth concerns and continued declines in commodities weighed on sentiment. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) both recovered from the early declines and traded marginally positive although weakness in tech and financials capped gains in Australia, while recent flows into JPY restricted upside for the Japanese benchmark. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) and Hang Seng (+0.1%) were initially lower amid growth and trade-related uncertainty, while the PBoC also recently noted that China’s economy is under increasing downward pressure. However, Chinese markets then recovered as officials continued to pledge measures to support businesses including wider tax cuts and with China also upbeat following record-breaking Singles Day sales. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively flat with price action contained as pressure from the improvement in regional sentiment was counterbalanced by the BoJ presence in the market.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9476 (Prev. 6.9329)

PBoC quarterly monetary policy implementation report reiterated it will maintain prudent and neutral policy, while it added that it will change policy only as appropriate to make the financial sector better serve the real economy. (Newswires)

China's Finance Minister said China will step up tax cuts, further lower fees for companies and will lower tax burden for exporters, while the China State Administration of Taxation chief said they are to implement a greater and broader scale tax reduction to support the private sector. (Newswires)

UK/EU/US

UK PM May was forced to drop her plan for an emergency cabinet meeting on Monday to approve a Brexit deal as she faced strong opposition from both her cabinet and the EU, which lessens the likelihood for an EU summit taking place later this month. (Independent) As a reminder, Brexit negotiators said on Friday that a draft treaty is close and that both sides were aiming for political approval this week, while separate reports noted that the EU is to require more movement from the UK on Brexit backstop. (FT/Newswires) UK Government source saying that no British cabinet meeting was ever scheduled for today, Brexit negotiations are still ongoing. (Newswires)

Top Brexiteers have told UK PM May that they remain deeply opposed to her Chequers plan with sources suggesting negotiators on both sides had agreed it would be impossible for the UK to unilaterally exit its backstop on Northern Ireland. (Guardian). Furthermore, The Telegraph reported that senior Tory backbenchers and DUP figures are to insist they will vote against PM May’s proposals unless she backs down. (Telegraph) Two ministers told the BBC that they believe there is little chance that PM May’s deal would get the Parliament’s backing. (BBC)

European Commission President Juncker said on Sunday that he thinks EU and UK are edging closer to a definitive Brexit deal that will be concluded in the coming weeks. (Newswires)

UK Trade Secretary Fox said a contentious number of issues remain for a Brexit deal to be reached and that UK may not be able to reach a deal on its departure from the EU. (Newswires)

Former UK Foreign Minister Boris Johnson accused the UK government of being on the brink of total surrender in Brexit negotiations, while he stated UK PM May recommended staying in the EU customs union under backstop and abdicating power to leave the backstop. (Telegraph)

Four UK ministers who support 'Remain' are said to be near to quitting PM May's government. (Newswires)

Former UK Minster Greening has said that UK PM May's possible deal won't pass parliament, the deal is over (Newswires)

UK PM May spokesman says there is nothing to suggest that other ministers are thinking about resigning and the Cabinet has backed PM May in moving forward on a Brexit deal, and expects the Cabinet to continue to do so. This follows weekend reports that four UK ministers who support ‘remain’ are said to be near to quitting the PM’s government. (Newswires)

Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development said UK employers expect to raise median base pay by 2% in the 12-months to September 2019. (Newswires)

Italy is seeking to lower its budget 2019 growth forecasts to between 1.0%-1.2% from 1.5% to get an EU budget deal. Italian Deputy PM Salvini said on Sunday that the Italian government could halt EU budget decisions. (Newswires)

Italy's PM Conte and Deputy PM's Salvini and Di Maio are to meet today to discuss the budget. (Newswires) However, there were contradicting reports from the PM’s office that PM Conte is not holding a budget meeting ahead of the re-submission deadline tomorrow, while ANSA reported that Deputy PM Di Maio did not attend talks. (Newswires/ANSA)

EU Commission President Juncker saying they are working at all levels to avoid escalation of trade conflicts with the US and will see Trump at the G20 summit in Buenos Aires. (Newswires)

US House Democrats are to probe US President Trump’s role regarding hush payments in 2016, while there were also reports that Federal prosecutors have gathered evidence that US President Trump participated in hush money payments to Stormy Daniels and Karen McDougal which would violate campaign laws. (WSJ) in related news, US House Democrats are to probe US President Trump for targeting CNN and Washington Post, while they are also expected to probe Trump’s actions related to Amazon and AT&T. (Axios/Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

BoE's Broadbent (Neutral) says limited and gradual rate guidance does not mean 1 rate hike per year precisely and there are signs that there will be somewhat weaker UK economic growth in Q4, adding that UK wage growth is materially higher and is now seeing signs of domestic inflation pressure. Broadbent also said reaching a Brexit deal is still the most likely outcome in his opinion;

ECB's VP de Guindos says the ECB is on track to policy normalisation; adding that downside risks have become more prominent and spillover from Italy have been quite contained. Also citing that Italy is the most prominent case of debt sustainability concerns. (Newswires)

PBoC advisor Ma Jun saying that pressure on the yuan could ease. (Newswires) PBoC said it has extended their 350bln yuan currency swap with the US for another 3 years. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Major European indices are mixed, with Germany’s DAX (-0.8%) lagging, weighed on by Infineon (-5.3%) following a projected revenue decline and SAP (-3.2%) after the company stated they are taking over Qualtrics International. UK’s FTSE 100 (+0.2%) is outperforming amid currency effects and as several big names are in the green (BHP +2.8%, Shire +2.3%, Anglo American +2.0%) outweighing the significant losses for British American Tobacco (-9.1%) and Imperial Brands (-4.1%) following reports of FDA commissioner pursuing a ban on menthol cigarettes. Similarly, sectors are mixed with IT names lagging and energy names outperforming, with FTSE giant BP (+1.8%) benefiting from the rebound in oil.

In terms of individual equities, Telecom Italia (+4.6%) are leading the Stoxx 600 after reports in Italian press that the Italian government are pushing a fibre deal with the Co. Elsewhere, Rio Tinto (+3.4%) rose to the top of the UK benchmark following the completion of a share-buyback programme. 

FX

USD - The Dollar is firmly back in the ascendency, albeit partly due to underperformance in major counterparts due to specific bearish factors. However, the DXY has extended recovery gains beyond 97.000 and through its previous ytd peak to top out just shy of 97.600 at 97.583, with bulls now eyeing relatively strong Fib resistance around 97.871 ahead of 98.000.

GBP - More Brexit-related weakness in Sterling has tipped Cable through another big figure, and just under 1.2850 at one stage, while Eur/Gbp has rebounded further from recent sub-0.8700 lows towards 0.8775 on latest threats of revolt within the UK Government and time running out fast to reach a withdrawal deal with the EU. From a technical perspective, nearest support in Cable comes in around 1.2810, which coincides with a Fib and decent option expiry interest.

EUR - The single currency is also under considerable pressure, and after triggering stops at 1.1300 vs the Greenback, losses accumulated quickly to 1.1250 where hefty bids stalled further downside for a while. The catalyst, ongoing Italian-EU budget angst ahead of Tuesday’s deadline for the Government to resubmit a fiscal plan, and another meeting between key Roman officials later today. Note also, 1.1 bn option expiries roll off at the 1.1250 strike, with the same size capping any rebounds to 1.1300.

CHF/AUD - Both around 0.4-0.45% weaker vs a generally bid Usd, with the France testing 1.1000 and Aud back below 0.7200 amidst renewed weakness in the Yuan.

NZD - The Kiwi is holding up moderately better than its antipodean peer, as Nzd/Usd maintains 0.6700+ status (just) and the Aud/Nzd cross retests support/bids around 1.0700.

CAD/JPY - Relative outperformers, or at least keeping pace with the Usd as the Loonie pivots 1.3200 and derives underlying support from a rebound in oil prices, while the latter pares losses from circa 114.20 to just above 114.00 due to its greater safe-haven allure.

EM - Broad declines in regional currencies vs the resurgent Dollar, but with Usd/Try slipping back from 5.5000+ levels in wake of Turkish current account data revealing another y/y improvement.

COMMODITIES

WTI (+0.4%) and Brent (+1.0%) bounced back with a vengeance as markets had the first opportunity to digest developments from the JMMC meeting during the weekend. The complex was on track for the longest losing streak since 1984, before Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih said the kingdom plans to reduce oil supply by 500K BPD in December due to a seasonal demand decline. Meanwhile, the JMMC decided not to take decisions on market adjustments on Sunday, with UAE’s Energy Minister noting that 2019 will require a change in OPEC strategy, adding that the new strategy is definitely not going to involve hiking output. Furthermore, in early European trade, the Kuwaiti Oil Minister stated that oil exporters discussed some kind of supply cut for next year but no volume was mentioned. Note: weekly API and DoE inventory data have been pushed back by a day due to US Veterans’ day.

Elsewhere, gold (-0.1%) fell to levels last seen in mid-October as the yellow metal tracked USD moves with the DXY reaching new YTD highs in early European trade. Meanwhile, copper is taking a breather from the recent sell-off and nickel extended losses to hit 11-month lows, pressured by concerns of slowing Chinese demand for steel.

At the weekend JMMC meeting, the committee decided not to take decisions on market adjustment, while Saudi Arabia Energy Minister Al-Falih said it is too premature for OPEC to discuss production cuts but stated that Saudi will reduce oil supply by 500k bpd in December amid seasonal decline in demand. (Newswires)

Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih says that they need to cut 1mln BPD from the Oct. level; adding that he cannot promise that there is no consideration of disbanding OPEC. (Newswires)

Russian average daily oil production stood at 11.39mln barrels between November 1st to 11th. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

UK Foreign Minister Hunt is to meet the Saudi Crown Prince in regard to the killing of Journalist Khashoggi. This comes after Turkish President Erdogan said he gave Britain, US, France, Germany and Saudi access to the audio recording of the journalist’s killing. (Times/Washington Post)

FIXED INCOME

The pace has slowed somewhat further, but Bunds and Gilts have both extended gains to marginal new highs on Eurex and Liffe, at 160.39 and 122.47 respectively (+36 and +65 ticks on the day) amidst ongoing/heightened Brexit and Italian budget anxiety, which have taken their toll of BTPs, the Gbp and Eur along with wider risk sentiment. Note, the 10 year Italian bond is back below 122.00 and close to a 121.85 base vs 122.59 at one stage, while US Treasuries have also latched on to the safe-haven bid in EU benchmarks with the curve faller again, albeit volumes crimped by Veterans Day. Back to Bunds, and technically speaking 160.56-58 looms next in terms of upside objectives.

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) CEO says Volkswagen will offer cheaper electric vehicles than Tesla (TSLA) and will have larger scale effects
Italy's Deputy PM Di Maio says respecting EU's limits on the budget is suicide; according to ANSA
Italy's PM Conte is not holding a budget meeting ahead of the re-submission deadline tomorrow; according to the PM's office
Italian Deputy PM Di Maio reportedly did not attend talks ahead of budget re-submission; according to ANSA
analysis_details: • This contradicts earlier reports that Italy's PM Conte and Deputy PM's Salvini and Di Maio are to meet today to discuss the budget.

WTI (+0.4%) and Brent (+1.0%) bounced back with a vengeance as markets had the first opportunity to digest developments from the JMMC meeting during the weekend. The complex was on track for the longest losing streak since 1984, before Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih said the kingdom plans to reduce oil supply by 500K BPD in December due to a seasonal demand decline. Meanwhile, the JMMC decided not to take decisions on market adjustments on Sunday, with UAE’s Energy Minister noting that 2019 will require a change in OPEC strategy, adding that the new strategy is definitely not going to involve hiking output. Furthermore, in early European trade, the Kuwaiti Oil Minister stated that oil exporters discussed some kind of supply cut for next year but no volume was mentioned. Note: weekly API and DoE inventory data have been pushed back by a day due to US Veterans’ day.

Elsewhere, gold (-0.2%) fell to levels last seen in mid-October as the yellow metal tracked USD moves with the DXY reaching new YTD highs in early European trade. Meanwhile, copper is taking a breather from the recent sell-off and nickel extended losses to hit 11-month lows, pressured by concerns of slowing Chinese demand for steel.

subject: FX Morning Colour: Pound worst of a bad bunch, Euro not faring much better
content:
USD

The Dollar is firmly back in the ascendency, albeit partly due to underperformance in major counterparts due to specific bearish factors. However, the DXY has extended recovery gains beyond 97.000 and through its previous ytd peak to top out just shy of 97.600 at 97.583, with bulls now eyeing relatively strong Fib resistance around 97.871 ahead of 98.000.

GBP

More Brexit-related weakness in Sterling has tipped Cable through another big figure, and just under 1.2850 at one stage, while Eur/Gbp has rebounded further from recent sub-0.8700 lows towards 0.8775 on latest threats of revolt within the UK Government and time running out fast to reach a withdrawal deal with the EU. From a technical perspective, nearest support in Cable comes in around 1.2810, which coincides with a Fib and decent option expiry interest.

EUR  

The single currency is also under considerable pressure, and after triggering stops at 1.1300 vs the Greenback, losses accumulated quickly to 1.1250 where hefty bids stalled further downside for a while. The catalyst, ongoing Italian-EU budget angst ahead of Tuesday’s deadline for the Government to resubmit a fiscal plan, and another meeting between key Roman officials later today. Note also, 1.1 bn option expiries roll off at the 1.1250 strike, with the same size capping any rebounds to 1.1300.

CHF/AUD

Both around 0.4-0.45% weaker vs a generally bid Usd, with the France testing 1.1000 and Aud back below 0.7200 amidst renewed weakness in the Yuan.

NZD

The Kiwi is holding up moderately better than its antipodean peer, as Nzd/Usd maintains 0.6700+ status (just) and the Aud/Nzd cross retests support/bids around 1.0700.

CAD/JPY

Relative outperformers, or at least keeping pace with the Usd as the Loonie pivots 1.3200 and derives underlying support from a rebound in oil prices, while the latter pares losses from circa 114.20 to just above 114.00 due to its greater safe-haven allure.

EM

Broad declines in regional currencies vs the resurgent Dollar, but with Usd/Try slipping back from 5.5000+ levels in wake of Turkish current account data revealing another y/y improvement.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

12th November 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets eventually traded mostly positive but with gains limited as some cautiousness lingered from the uninspiring performance on Wall St last Friday, where ongoing global growth concerns and continued declines in commodities weighed on sentiment. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) both recovered from the early declines and traded marginally positive although weakness in tech and financials capped gains in Australia, while recent flows into JPY restricted upside for the Japanese benchmark. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) and Hang Seng (+0.1%) were initially lower amid growth and trade-related uncertainty, while the PBoC also recently noted that China’s economy is under increasing downward pressure. However, Chinese markets then recovered as officials continued to pledge measures to support businesses including wider tax cuts and with China also upbeat following record-breaking Singles Day sales. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively flat with price action contained as pressure from the improvement in regional sentiment was counterbalanced by the BoJ presence in the market.

FTSE

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) –The largest clinical trial undertaken so far to assess a new class of diabetes pills shows that the Co’s Farixga can prevent heart failure and cut the risk of kidney problems in a broad range of patients. (Newswires)

BT (BT/ LN) – BT Global Services is planning to cut about 80% of their customer base in order to become a leaner business. This comes after the accounting scandal at BT Italia in 2016. (FT)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 12th November 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets eventually traded mostly positive but with gains limited as some cautiousness lingered from the uninspiring performance on Wall St last Friday
  • GBP/USD gapped lower towards 1.2900 after reports that UK PM May cancelled an emergency cabinet meeting which severely lessens the likelihood of an EU summit later this month
  • Sources suggested EU and UK negotiators had agreed it would be impossible for the UK to unilaterally exit its backstop on Northern Ireland
  • Looking ahead, the calendar includes a lack of tier 1 data, BoE’s Broadbent, ECB’s de Guindos and Lautenschlaeger, Fed’s Daly. US Veteran’s Day – no market closures.

ASIA

Asian equity markets eventually traded mostly positive but with gains limited as some cautiousness lingered from the uninspiring performance on Wall St last Friday, where ongoing global growth concerns and continued declines in commodities weighed on sentiment. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) both recovered from the early declines and traded marginally positive although weakness in tech and financials capped gains in Australia, while recent flows into JPY restricted upside for the Japanese benchmark. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) and Hang Seng (+0.1%) were initially lower amid growth and trade-related uncertainty, while the PBoC also recently noted that China’s economy is under increasing downward pressure. However, Chinese markets then recovered as officials continued to pledge measures to support businesses including wider tax cuts and with China also upbeat following record-breaking Singles Day sales. Finally, 10yr JGBs were relatively flat with price action contained as pressure from the improvement in regional sentiment was counterbalanced by the BoJ presence in the market.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9476 (Prev. 6.9329)

PBoC quarterly monetary policy implementation report reiterated it will maintain prudent and neutral policy, while it added that it will change policy only as appropriate to make the financial sector better serve the real economy. (Newswires)

China's Finance Minister said China will step up tax cuts, further lower fees for companies and will lower tax burden for exporters, while the China State Administration of Taxation chief said they are to implement a greater and broader scale tax reduction to support the private sector. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said on Friday that the US is seeking friendly and constructive dialogue with China, while there were also comments from a Chinese Official that China has committed itself to working with the US in a non-confrontational way and that economic teams will seek mutually acceptable solution on trade. (Newswires)


UK/EU

UK PM May was forced to drop her plan for an emergency cabinet meeting on Monday to approve a Brexit deal as she faced strong opposition from both her cabinet and the EU, which lessens the likelihood for an EU summit taking place later this month. (Independent) As a reminder, Brexit negotiators said on Friday that a draft treaty is close and that both sides were aiming for political approval this week, while separate reports noted that the EU is to require more movement from the UK on Brexit backstop. (FT/Newswires)

Top Brexiteers have told UK PM May that they remain deeply opposed to her Chequers plan with sources suggesting negotiators on both sides had agreed it would be impossible for the UK to unilaterally exit its backstop on Northern Ireland. (Guardian). Furthermore, The Telegraph reported that senior Tory backbenchers and DUP figures are to insist they will vote against PM May’s proposals unless she backs down. (Telegraph) Two ministers told the BBC that they believe there is little chance that PM May’s deal would get the Parliament’s backing. (BBC)

European Commission President Juncker said on Sunday that he thinks EU and UK are edging closer to a definitive Brexit deal that will be concluded in the coming weeks. (Newswires)

UK Trade Secretary Fox said a contentious number of issues remain for a Brexit deal to be reached and that UK may not be able to reach a deal on its departure from the EU. (Newswires)

Former UK Foreign Minister Boris Johnson accused the UK government of being on the brink of total surrender in Brexit negotiations, while he stated UK PM May recommended staying in the EU customs union under backstop and abdicating power to leave the backstop. (Telegraph)

Four UK ministers who support 'Remain' are said to be near to quitting PM May's government. (Newswires)

Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development said UK employers expect to raise median base pay by 2% in the 12-months to September 2019. (Newswires)

Italy is seeking to lower its budget 2019 growth forecasts to between 1.0%-1.2% from 1.5% to get an EU budget deal. Italian Deputy PM Salvini said on Sunday that the Italian government could halt EU budget decisions. (Newswires)


FX

In FX markets, the USD held on to recent gains and reclaimed the 97.00 level to the upside as its major counterparts struggled overnight in which EUR/USD nearly gave up the 1.1300 handle and GBP/USD gapped lower towards 1.2900 after reports that UK PM May cancelled an emergency cabinet meeting which severely lessens the likelihood of an EU summit later this month. Elsewhere, commodity-linked currencies saw early support from a rebound in oil prices after Saudi announced to reduce its exports by 500k bpd next month although antipodeans the gave back most the gains in tandem with a softer CNH and firmer greenback.

Mexico President-Elect AMLO said he will not change banking laws and does not intend to make changes to legal framework in financial sector during the first period of his administration, while he will also not make any fiscal or economic changes in his first 3yrs. (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed overnight in which WTI crude futures found some respite from its 10th consecutive loss on Friday, as prices were supported by news that Saudi plans to reduce oil supply by 500k bpd next month. Elsewhere, gold prices were subdued as the greenback extended on gains, while copper nursed some of its recent losses following the mild improvement in risk tone.

At the weekend JMMC meeting, the committee decided not to take decisions on market adjustment, while Saudi Arabia Energy Minister Al-Falih said it is too premature for OPEC to discuss production cuts but stated that Saudi will reduce oil supply by 500k bpd in December amid seasonal decline in demand. (Newswires)

Russian Energy Minister Novak said December output is forecast at around the November level, while he also said they are theoretically open to output cuts if OPEC+ reach a consensus. (Newswires)

OPEC+ technical monitoring panel puts October oil cut compliance at 104% vs. 111% in September. (Newswires)

US Treasury Department extended the deadline again for Rusal customers to wind down their contracts and business with the Co.. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICS

UK Foreign Minister Hunt is to meet the Saudi Crown Prince in regard to the killing of Journalist Khashoggi. This comes after Turkish President Erdogan said he gave Britain, US, France, Germany and Saudi access to the audio recording of the journalist’s killing. (Times/Washington Post)

US

Although the Fed’s statement on Thursday was largely considered hawkish, Treasuries resumed its role as a haven amid the stock slide and renewed concerns around the Chinese economy (PBOC sees downward pressures on China growth, in its Q3 monpol implementation report, which brought out buyers in Tsys), with yields coming in by between c.3-4bps by settlement; major curve spreads were generally biased towards flattening (of up to around 1.5bps) though the 5s30s and 10s30s part of the curve was modestly wider. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 11 ticks higher at 118-04.

US President Trump was reportedly telling people he wants to replace Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross by the end of the year. (CNBC)

US House Democrats are to probe US President Trump’s role regarding hush payments in 2016, while there were also reports that Federal prosecutors have gathered evidence that US President Trump participated in hush money payments to Stormy Daniels and Karen McDougal which would violate campaign laws. (WSJ) in related news, US House Democrats are to probe US President Trump for targeting CNN and Washington Post, while they are also expected to probe Trump’s actions related to Amazon and AT&T. (Axios/Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades relatively flat after having shrugged-off opening weakness and Friday's Wall St losses
content:
Asia equity markets trade indecisive but off worst levels after having shrugged-off most the opening losses and the weak performance on Wall St last Friday, where ongoing global growth concerns and continued weakness in commodities weighed on sentiment. ASX 200 (Unch) and Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) both recovered from the early declines to trade marginally positive but with weakness in tech and financials capping gains in Australia, while recent flows into JPY limited upside for the Japanese benchmark. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) and Hang Seng (+0.2%) are choppy amid growth and trade-related uncertainty, while the PBoC recently noted that China’s economy is under increasing downward pressure and officials have continued to pledge measures to support businesses including wider tax cuts.

In FX markets, the USD holds on to recent gains and tests the 97.00 level to the upside as its major counterparts struggle with EUR/USD at the weaker end of the 1.1300 handle, while GBP/USD gapped lower towards the 1.2900 level after reports that UK PM May cancelled an emergency cabinet meeting due to strong opposition regarding her Brexit plans which severely lessens the likelihood of an EU summit later this month. Elsewhere, commodity-linked currencies have nursed Friday’s losses as they find solace from early strength in oil prices after Saudi announced to reduce its exports by 500k bpd next month, while JPY-crosses are slightly higher amid the somewhat improved risk sentiment but still have far to got to get back to last week’s highs.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are relatively flat with price action contained as pressure from the slight improvement in regional sentiment is counterbalanced by the BoJ presence in the market for a reserved JPY 475bln of JGBs.
